ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also had asynchronous discussion posts every Thursday.
There were also virtual tutorial sessions once a week!

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I greatly improved my spoken chinese and knowledge of grammatical structures
I expanded my vocabulary, learned more grammar, improved my tones, and developed better sentences.
More Chinese vocabulary, ways to tackle grammar, and giving/writing smoother oral presentations and essays.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was sometimes hard to concentrate because class was so heavily lecture-based. I think including more interactive elements would be helpful.

I love how this course was a small group of students since it allowed for greater engagement with both my Professor and peers. Daily homework may seem annoying, but it truly helped me learn more. I wish we received more opportunities to speak in class or with our peers. I struggle to form coherent sentences and fluidly conversing with others, at times, so I definitely would have found this helpful.

The course is well-structured for learning but can feel somewhat repetitive. It requires a lot of self-learning and guidance, though Liu Laoshi and the TFs are really available and helpful as well. The immersive aspect was great, so you are guaranteed to improve to some extent, even with low levels of engagement.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think Chinese is an especially hard class to teach over zoom, so I give the professors a lot of credit for what they managed to do this semester. I think asking the class questions and allowing us to do presentations helped with class engagement.

Online classes worked, however, for a language class, there are always difficulties. For example, when reciting a passage from a text, everyone's audio is out of synch. In addition, casual partner work was pretty much eliminated, but breakout rooms as its substitution were quite successful. I'm not sure if there can be any improvements since the Chinese Department already has tried so hard to give their students the best possible learning experience!

This virtual version of the course was dramatically weakened. The typical lecture-style class made it easy to stop paying attention. The cold calling is effective and helps students stay attentive. The breakout rooms were alright but also made it easy to slip out of Chinese and get off track. Id just rather take this class in-person.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!! The professors are wonderful, and just the simple act of listening to Chinese everyday will lead to your own language skills improvement.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. I loved learning Chinese, as it was fun and interesting. The professor did an amazing job at facilitating engagement and curiosity, and I didn't mind waking up every morning to learn! You get what you put into it, and I think this course truly helps you improve your Chinese if you work hard enough.

I would definitely recommend it to heritage students looking for some level of improvement in Chinese. Even in a virtual format, we were able to get to know some other Chinese-American students and share mutual awkwardness in our illiteracy.
